title: Luxembourg’s Mamer Offers Green Space, Short Commutes and a Very In-Demand Private School
text:
The municipality of Mamer, which lies six miles outside Luxembourg City and is surrounded by open fields, forest and woodland, offers working families and couples both green space and a short commute to work.



The A6 motorway, which links Belgium with Luxembourg and runs through the area, is a traffic-jam hotspot but Mamer is no less popular for it. This is due to its attractive semi-rural setting, family-friendly amenities and community-minded population.



The European School, Luxembourg II, on the neighborhood’s border with the town of Bertrange, is a multilingual private school that offers the European Baccalaureate qualification, has increased its allure, particularly with expats and as a result has become more cosmopolitan.

More: Grosse Pointe Farms: An Old-Timey Small-Town in Detroit

Boundaries

Mamer, one of Luxembourg’s 102 municipalities, sits to the west of Luxembourg city center and covers 27 square kilometers. It has, as previously mentioned, the A6 motorway running through it, as well as a railway line and the N6 road, another artery linking Luxembourg City to the Belgian border.



Mamer, Holzem and Capellen are the area’s three main villages. Mamer is the largest and sits to the east of the municipality. Holzem lies to the south and Capellen is positioned in its northwest corner.

The area is mostly formed of forest, woodland and open fields and it features the southern end of the hilly Mamer River valley. Its southern border lies just north of the E44 road, its western and northern borders cross through countryside and Rue de Mamer lies on its eastern side.

Price Range



Prices are high in the city center because of demand and a lack of stock, which makes areas on its fringes, such as Mamer appealing. Values here are about 30% to 50% lower than in the city center, according to Christophe Muller, director of sales at Luxembourg Sotheby’s International Realty.



From July 2018 to June 2019, the average sales price of a house was €1,192,373 (US$1,325,817 million) or €5,163 per square meter while the average sales price of an apartment was €784,085 or €7,130 per square meter, according to the Habitat Observatory, a department of the Ministry of Housing in Luxembourg.



The most popular price range at the upper end of the market in Mamer, however, is between €1.5 million and €2.3 million, according to Mr. Filipe Rebelo, a real estate agent at Engel & Volkers Luxembourg.

For this price, buyers would get a modern family home in good condition with four bedrooms and a garden, he added. It is possible to buy a detached house for €1 million, but it will probably need some work, according to Mr. Rebelo and Mr. Muller, who add that some homes can cost as much as €4.5 million.



More: Muthaiga is Nairobi’s Most-Affluent Neighborhood, Offering Privacy and Lush Landscapes

From July 2018 to June 2019, existing apartments sold for between €4,235 per square meter and €7,516 per square meter, while new apartments sold for between €6,391 per square meter and €8,306 per square meter, according to the Habitat Observatory.



One of the most expensive homes currently on the market is a former mill building dating to the 1420s set on 19 acres of land. The five-bedroom house with period features, contemporary fittings, a spa and a swimming pool is for sale for €4.48 million with Luxembourg Sotheby’s International Realty.

Housing Stock



Single-family homes (54.6%) and apartments (45.3%) are the main housing type in the area.



About 60% of Mamer’s housing stock is older and mostly date to the 1970s and ’80s (there are a number of period farmhouses and houses, too, some of which date back to the 1500s) and 30% are new builds.



There has been a boom in construction in the area—with developers capitalizing on the recent spike in population. Most land-buying opportunities are snapped up by developers rather than private owners.



Most new homes are terraced family homes and apartments and they tend to be located in Mamer village on secondary roads off the A6 motorway for ease of access. Some properties benefit from rural views, as they back onto open fields and come with large grounds.



Mamer Castle is used as a town hall. Ipigott / Wikepedia

What Makes It Unique



Mamer suits cosmopolitan families because it has good schools, play areas and everyday amenities and a busy cultural and social events schedule, which keep people of all ages entertained throughout the year.



The area has many hiking paths and biking trails, some of which pass through forest and continue out to the Juckelsbësch Plateau, a high plain in the area, according to Mr. Muller, and includes the Mamer River valley, which has great countryside along it.



There are 19 playgrounds as well as sports clubs, attractive buildings such as the Mamer Castle, a château now used as a town hall, and the remains of Roman thermal baths.



More: Mallorca’s Port Andratx is a Private Paradise on the Water

There is plenty to do after work and on the weekends, Mr. Rebelo said. “It is still like a village, and there are many community activities,” he said.



“All amenities are within walking distance and it is in the vicinity of nature as it is surrounded by forest and natural parks,” Mr. Muller said. “It is the perfect balance between city and nature.”



Residents either drive into the city, which takes 30 minutes, cycle (using the Vel’oh self-service bike scheme), take the train (10 minutes) or the bus (35 minutes). Night owls can hop on the Night Rider bus, which offers affordable late-night services. The tram route in the city is being extended and there are plans for a further extension to Mamer “after 2021,” but no date has been given yet.



In addition to its convenient location, the area has a high street known as Route d’Arlon with everyday amenities such as a bakery and wine and grocery shops. It is less than a mile from Belle Etoile, a shopping mall in Bertrange with global clothing brands and restaurants.



Luxury Amenities



European School, Luxembourg II, whose sister school is in Kirchberg, a neighborhood in Luxembourg City located eight miles away, is popular because the majority of residents in its capital city are expats—only 20% of the population are Luxembourgian.



The Kinneksbond school campus, a Luxembourgish private school for nursery, preschool and primary age children, is a magnet for wealthy families, with its modern buildings and multi- sports facilities.



Located on the same site is a cultural center with the same name, which has a 480-person auditorium where music, opera, drama performances and concerts are held. Set in Mamer, the whole complex was built in 2010.

More: Cultural Riches and Traditional Architecture in Kyoto’s Kamigyo Ward

An array of high-quality facilities can be found at the Nicolas Frantz sports hall, which was named after the Mamer-born bicycle racer who won the Tour de France twice, and the François Trausch football stadium and sports complex, currently home to the Mamer 32 football club, and Tennis Club Cap On line.



Mamer has a number of good restaurants including I’Ultimo, an Italian eatery with a contemporary interior, La Pulcinella, a French restaurant, and La Croccante, a pizza restaurant.



Diners after an impressive menu however should head to Domaine de La Gaichel, a Michelin-starred restaurant on the Luxembourg and Belgium border, about nine miles away. It is housed in a four-star inn and serves traditional fare and has a terrace overlooking parkland.



Bonifas restaurant is a red stucco French restaurant located a 10-minute drive from Mamer, which, according to the Michelin website serves “popular dishes in a bistro ambience.”



In Mamer village, there is the Philippe Bourtenbourg wine shop, and Kichechef, a home furnishings shop that stocks internationally known brands such as Miele, Gaggenau and Hülsta, is located between Capellen and Mamer villages. Roche Bobois, the French furniture brand, has a store less than three miles away in Bertange.

Who Lives There



As of Jan. 2019, there were 9,589 living in Mamer, according to the Statistics Portal, which is owned by the Luxembourg State, and the average resident earns €52,140 per year, as of 2016 and 2017, according to the same website.



The population grew to 9,529 from 7,620, between 2010 and 2017. And 51% are foreigners.



Most people are aged between 30 and 50 years of age, Mr. Muller said.



Most people work for international companies such as the Nato Support and Procurement Agency, which is based in Capellen and has a workforce of 1,200 people, and European institutions such as the European International Bank, the European Investment Fund and the European Court of Justice or in the finance and banking sector for firms such as KPMG, Deloitte, EY and PwC.



More: Breathtaking Views and Impeccable Architecture in Phoenix’s Premier Enclave, Paradise Valley

Finance and banking sectors are large employers, as the sovereign state of Luxembourg is a top EU hub for international financial institutions due to its business-friendly tax regime. More firms have relocated there since Brexit.



Notable Residents



Jean Claude-Juncker, the president of the European Commission, lives in Mamer, according to the Luxembourg Times.



Previous residents include Nicolas Frantz and Josy Barthel, a mid-distance runner, who is the state’s only Olympic gold medallist. He was also born in Mamer and has a high school in the neighborhood named after him, known as the Lycée Josy Barthel.



Outlook



The market is quite aggressive because there is big demand for homes and homes are in short supply, Mr. Rebelo said. “Prices have continued to increase and the market sentiment is positive.”



The global downturn was not felt that much in the property market in Luxembourg City, he added.

“Prices increased after [the] 2008 global financial crash then plateaued and have since started to rise again,” Ne. Rebels said. “Values have increased by 5% year on year in the city and its surrounding areas.”



From July 2018 to June 2019, a total of 202 houses and 309 apartments were put on the market in Mamer, according to the Habitat Observatory.
